newsitem.title: UK: European rate moves make new UK cut more likely.
newsitem.headline: European rate moves make new UK cut more likely.

text.p: Thursday's interest rate cuts across continental Europe make it marginally more likely that Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke will cut rates again.

But economists said favourable domestic data will remain the main factor determining whether Clarke cuts rates for the fifth time since last December, either at the September 4 monetary meeting or in October.
Following the Bundesbank's unexpectedly large repo rate cut which triggered moves elsewhere, the short sterling strip has shifted upwards as it reassessed the future path of UK rates.
September and December futures, at 94.27 and 94.28, are now at least starting to think about another quarter-point rate cut, although they still discount unchanged rates.
March 1997 short sterling has changed its tune more dramatically and is no longer fully factoring in a rate rise by the first quarter. It is trading at 94.08 compared with 93.92 on Wednesday.
"The (July) retail sales figures helped to spark off a rally in short sterling and this was reinforced by news of a 30 bp reduction in the German repo rate," said Philip Shaw of Union Discount.
"Nevertheless, UK markets are still reluctant to price in fully a further easing in monetary policy."
Retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.6 percent in July.
"I think trends in European rates are fairly marginal in Clarke's decision, but yesterday's moves will have helped him slightly," said James McKay, international economist at Paine Webber.

"I have a feeling he will focus on what he has been focussing on in the past half-year -- falling inflation and falling manufacturing output. I suspect a rate cut may well happen in September. If not, the focus will turn to October."
Data in the last month are generally seen as having gone Clarke's way in his disagreement with Bank of England Governor Eddie George over the future course of monetary policy.
Alongside the fall in retail sales, second-quarter GDP data showed manufacturing flat and overall growth below-trend, while both retail and producer prices remain benign.
However, Paul Turnbull of Merrill Lynch believes continued evidence of rising final demand will prompt the Chancellor to leave rates where they are.
Turnbull, who fears the economy could overheat next year with growth around four percent, points to a firm trend in retail sales, despite the July fall, and strong business surveys.
Second-quarter GDP, which grew 1.8 percent year-on-year, is fairly buoyant if the problems of the stock cycle are excluded, he argues.

Jonathan Loynes of HSBC Midland says the Confederation of British Industry's monthly trends survey for August, released overnight, shows a glimmer of hope for manufacturers but improvement in the coming months is likely to be slow.
"The twin evils of weak overseas demand and high stocks are still in evidence and could continue to depress output for a while longer," he said.
Shaw of Union Discount said the retail sales numbers strengthen his belief that UK rates have still not bottomed.
A general election is due by May 1997.
